question: 7 (b)
statement_html:
In an experiment involving a bacteria population, \(N(t)\) denotes the size of the population (measured in thousands of individuals) as a function of time, starting at \(t=0\). The initial population is \(N(0) = N_{0}\).

b) Suppose the population growth is governed by the differential equation

\(\displaystyle \frac{dN}{dt} = \frac{N^{2}}{(t+1)^{2}}\)

Find \(N(t)\) if \(N(0)=2\).
statement_latex:
In an experiment involving a bacteria population, $N(t)$ denotes the
size of the population (measured in thousands of individuals) as a
function of time, starting at $t=0$. The initial population is
$N(0) = N_{0}$.

b) Suppose the population growth is governed by the differential
equation

$\displaystyle \frac{dN}{dt} = \frac{N^{2}}{(t+1)^{2}}$

Find $N(t)$ if $N(0)=2$.
statement_raw:
In an experiment involving a bacteria population, <math> N(t) </math> denotes the size of the population (measured in thousands of individuals) as a function of time, starting at <math> t=0 </math>. The initial population is <math> N(0) = N_{0} </math>.

b) Suppose the population growth is governed by the differential equation

<math>
\displaystyle
\frac{dN}{dt} = \frac{N^{2}}{(t+1)^{2}}
</math>

Find <math> N(t) </math> if <math> N(0)=2 </math>.
